ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic to intermediate grammar and terms in Chinese. Learned about some cultural and common activities in China, particularly about famous places in Beijing and China.

I learned more vocabulary with specific units and grammar points to better converse in a formal and informal way. I also learned how to write essays on specific topics and respond to questions in Chinese.
a much better understanding of Chinese grammar patterns and colloquial language
I was able to dramatically improve my Chinese writing skills, as well as improve my reading skills.
grammar structures of higher level chinese

I learned the rudimentary grammar foundations that bring up the Chinese Language. In addition to building up my vocabulary, I was able to practice conversational and professional Chinese conversations with my classmates and Liu Laoshi.
Through the lessons we covered, not only did we learn grammar structure and tons of new vocabulary, but various aspects of Chinese culture.

I got so much better at reading, writing, and speaking Chinese through this class. I learned more about Chinese culture, and overall got a lot more comfortable with the language than I expected in just a few months.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: amazing pacing and great facilitation of learning for heritage Chinese students, greatly improves your chinese at a reasonable pace. Could not be conceivably improved at the moment.

Strengths: Required vocabulary and Chinese characters each day help me to solidify the learning of these terms. In class review of the textbook materials each day provides opportunities to ask questions and discuss the topic further.
Weaknesses: Not lots of opportunity for discussion in class, I would've liked to practice the grammar topics and have constructive feedback by the teacher a bit more since my fluency in speaking is not as good.
could involve more peer discussion/casual and real life conversation prompts

The group discussions and reading/grammar repetition helped me fully understand how to speak fluently and put the skills I learned into practice. One minor weakness is that I was a bit confused at the beginning of the course about grammar structure, as we only practiced speaking and did not write down the different structures. However, this improved as the course progressed.
Course is really good as is.

The strength of the class is that it is super engaging. Even though the class met 5 days a week, I did not once feel like it was too much. Liu Laoshi is also a strength, as she is a very patient, caring, and understanding professor. She was definitely one of the highlights of the class! The students were also very nice and our whole class got very close together because of the small setting. No weaknesses off the top of my mind!

The strengths are that the class is very well structured with clear expectations of what is expected of students in regards to homework and workload. However the weakness is that the workload can be lot at times.

Strengths: Fast-paced but absorbable, great professors

Weaknesses: I think more time could have been put into drilling different grammar structures to get more comfortable with them

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES ABSOLUTELY, taking the class with Liu Laoshi was the best decision of my semester and I really bonded with her. Amazing teacher and fabulous course to improve Chinese!

Yes! It is a great opportunity to strengthen your Chinese fluency by increasing the number of words you can use, read, and write as well as bettering your fluency in speaking Chinese. It also helped me make a lot of Chinese friends as we studied for class, got meals after class, and in general, saw each other every day.
yes
I would recommend this course to another student. Although the workload was a bit big, the extra amount of work is what helped dramatically improve my writing skills.

I would 110% recommend this course to another student. If you are a first-year seeking new friends, then it's a great opportunity! However, I would say that if you absolutely dislike Chinese, then the workload and daily quizzes might not be worth it for you. However, if you're just trying to finish the Chinese credit, then this course might change your opinion otherwise.
Definitely!
Yes, the professors are great, and you're bound to make some great friends from the class.
